main event: Two youths reported seeing a fast-traveling 'flying disc' pass over Ludington, Michigan, on April 21, 1949. The object looked like a comet with a tail and was observed heading west before disappearing over Lake Michigan.
interesting points: The flying disc was described as a 'coin with a tail a block long' and was white in color.
The observation indicated that there were no clouds over Ludington at the time of the sighting.
The report mentioned a postcard from an unknown woman in Eastern Michigan, near Detroit, who claimed to have seen similar objects and reached out to discuss the sighting with one of the observers.
Witnesses pursued flying discs over Homer, Michigan, about a week after the Ludington sighting, describing them as 10 inches in diameter and moving in wide circles parallel to the highway.
Additionally, there was a report of a mysterious glow and a burned area on the road in Ludington, along with rumors of unidentified material being tested by the Army Ballistic Research Lab.
sighted object: fast-traveling 'flying disc' resembling a comet with a tail
witnesses: Two youths, employees of the Post Milk Co.
